summary: in support of @allofthefeelings quest to make steves arc in endgame make sense:[[MORE]] There are only a few things left in the...
body:
in support of @allofthefeelings quest to make steves arc in endgame make sense:

There are only a few things left in the universe that Steve Rogers is sure of. And one of them, to be completely frank, is that it is deeply fucked up to be standing face-to-face with the goddamn Red Skull on Vormir.

“Look,” Steve says. “I gave you the stone back. So give me her.”

Red Skull smiles like a snake– with no lips to shield his teeth, he just seems to be threatening Steve. “That is not how it works.”

“Oh, screw you,” Steve says. “A soul for a soul. You get the stone. I get her.”

“The life of your friend will cost more than that,” Red Skull says, his voice like an oil slick in a July parking lot.

Steve has had just about Enough of this cryptic shit. He thought the Ancient one was pretentious, but man Red Skull could teach her a thing or two. “What do you want for Nat?” he says, slowly and carefully.

“You want her life, I need yours.”

Steve laughs. “What if I throw you off the cliff?” he says. “Will I get her back then?”

Red Skull shrugs. “You wouldn’t be the first to try it, Rogers. And you wouldn’t be the first to fail.”

“I won’t bargain lives.”

It seems almost silly to say, with all the sacrifices they’ve made. But Steve means it. He means it as hard as he can.

“If you want her future–”

“Yeah,” Steve waves dismissively. “I have to give up my–”

Red Skull smiles again, and Steve still hasn’t decided not to punch him. It’s a day that ends in a y, which makes it a nice day to punch Nazis. But he’s figured it out. He’s figured out the trade, and he extends his hand.

“Okay,” Steve says. “I give you my future. I give you the life I have. Give me her, and I give you that.”

Red Skull looks like he would raise an eyebrow, if he had any. “Explain.”

“It’s simple. You bring Nat back, and I won’t go back to 2023. I give you my life.” Steve smiles. “What do you say, Schmidt? You can tell your nazi buddies that you finally killed Captain America.”

Red Skull nods once. “I accept.”

Steve wakes in a pond on Vormir, a smile on his face. He wasn’t going to be able to go back, no. But he had still won.
body_abstract: in support of @allofthefeelings quest to make steves arc in endgame make sense:

tags: joy is a huge emotional payoff
summary: More on Expecting Death in our stories
title: More on Expecting Death in our stories
body:
I added a long complaint to a post that’s making the rounds about Avengers: Endgame and our expectations of death when it comes to final episodes, final books, final movies (or in this case final movie of Phases One-Through-Three or whatever they’re calling it). I argued that you can get just as much of an emotional payoff through joy as you can through Big Death. I cross-posted to my Dreamwidth and OMG people replied (I know! Conversation! in Fandom! Who could have imagined… wait…)

Responding to the comments brought about a one small, easy explanation of how joy could be a huge payoff in Endgame. I am 100% sure that I’m not the first person to come up with this idea, but I’m not in the Marvel fandom per se, so I can’t link to others’ versions even though I know they’re out there.

I wanted to write something about emerging victorious in the post specifically w/r/t Endgame–can you imagine that final fight, everywhere, all of the battles and the struggles and finally the StarkSnap, and all of the Enemy are dust, Thanos is dust, the Evil is defeated, and the film shows us Our Heroes, one by one, standing up, looking around, finding one another, we go from set battle scene to set battle scene and each hero is taking stock… as they make eye contact we go from one, to another, to another, exhausted, bloodied and bruised, but standing and seeing each other. 

But then we finally land on Tony, dying… and we all think this is it. This is The Death. We get Sad Peter. We get Sad Pepper. Tony begins to fade.

BUT WAIT

A Doctor-Strange-Brand-Name Portal opens next to Tony, and Doctor Strange steps through followed by Shuri, who promptly jabs Tony with a Wakandan Anti-Radiation Pen.

It would have been so easy. The screaming cheers on opening night would have deafened Times Square.

And then comes the Doylean question: what do we do about Robert Downey Junior not appearing in any more Avengers films?

Shit, son, if you can’t come up with a compelling reason for a man who has nearly died several times to step back and allow the next generation of heroes to step forward after introducing Captain Fucking Marvel, you don’t deserve to make movies.

tags: it's an Official tea party bc im positive pepper sent out memos
summary: The biggest injustice of Endgame is that there was no Rhodey/Morgan interaction. If for one second you think that her uncle...
body: The biggest injustice of Endgame is that there was no Rhodey/Morgan interaction. If for one second you think that her uncle Rhodey wasn’t at every official Stark Family Tea Party in his Sunday best, then you are outta your goddamn mind.

summary: *notes the pic in your blog header* Sorry, if you've mentioned this previously, but your thoughts on Thor in Endgame? Also......
question: *notes the pic in your blog header* Sorry, if you've mentioned this previously, but your thoughts on Thor in Endgame? Also... what MCU character deserves a solo movie? Aaaaand... if you had to read only one fanfic trope for the rest of forever what would it be?
answer:
These are such good questions - thank you! 

(Buckle up, because this answer is going to be a long one.) 

Thoughts on Thor in Endgame - Spoilers ahead obviously! 

Most of my answer to this question comes from an answer I’d written on Quora, but I’ve added a few things as well. Thor has always been my favorite Avenger, and even before that he was always my favorite Norse god, so I’m really happy to answer this one.

I know people have a lot of feelings about the movie, and I haven’t actually had a chance to write about my own feelings on it much. But one of the things I enjoyed most about Endgame was that everyone got a chance to do something that made their arc complete, for better or worse - i.e

  • Steve’s dance and his happy ending
  • Natasha sacrificing herself and finally wiping the red out of her ledger
  • Clint being willing to sacrifice himself and seeing the error of his ways as Ronin
  • Tony getting to have a few years of domestic bliss and being able to have one last positive conversation with his dad before he selflessly saved the world by giving his own life
  • Bruce and Hulk coming to a peaceful agreement to coexist

But my favorite of those moments was Thor’s visit to 2013 Asgard. 

Up to this point in the movie, Thor has been severely depressed. Though he pretends to be indifferent, it’s painfully obvious that he’s still suffering from all the trauma he’s been through in the last few years (not least of which was losing everyone he loved and failing in his fight with Thanos). His depression shows in his physical appearance and his mental attitude. 

Even when he gets to 2013 Asgard, he doesn’t initially have the motivation to carry out the mission he’s supposed to. It isn’t until Frigga notices him and offers her listening ear that Thor is forced to confront his feelings. His mother, the person who knows him the best, is the one that helps Thor work through those feelings, and I think it’s brilliantly done. Unlike with his friends, Thor is more willing to talk to his mother about how he feels (and for good reason - who wouldn’t feel comfortable confiding in Frigga?). 

He gets a chance to talk about what happened to him without fear of being judged or ridiculed. He knows his mother won’t think less of him because he failed at something - and she doesn’t. In fact, she gives him some really good advice in relation to that: “It’s time for you to stop being who you’re supposed to be, and start being who you are.”

It’s a simple bit of dialogue, but very powerful, and it gives Thor the confidence he needs to get himself together. 

In just that short span of time that he had a chance to talk to his mother, she helps him realize that he is still valuable, and more than that, he’s equal to the task he needs to perform. That confidence boost inspires him to call for his hammer. 

Mjölnir immediately flies into his hand. Softly, with glee, he says, “I’m still worthy!” It was enough to break my heart in the best way possible, and probably my favorite line of dialogue in the whole three hour movie. From that point on, we see Thor get his mojo back, and it’s beautiful. I think it was a great way to round out his arc if that’s what they’re choosing to do. But part of me is hoping that they actually use this as a kickoff point to give us more of his story post-Endgame.

And yeah, I liked chubby Berserker Thor. I also liked that they didn’t waste time showing us some unnecessary montage of him working out and losing weight again. I love that they had him fight as he was, and he was still a badass. Sure, we probably could’ve done without the melted ice cream and salad jokes, but on the whole, I wasn’t unhappy with the way Thor’s arc panned out. 

What MCU character deserves a solo movie? 

I’d actually love to see Thanos get his own movie. Aside from Loki, he’s probably been the most compelling villain for me. The difference between Thanos and Loki is that we got Loki’s “origin story” from the first Thor movie - it helped us understand who he was and where he came from, and it showed us how he ended up on the path that led him to where he was in the first Avengers movie. 

With Thanos, we really get no such backstory. Sure, he talks about it a little bit in Infinity War, but for me it just wasn’t enough. I want to see more than just a passing shot of Titan in all its glory. I want to see young Thanos, find out who Alars is - is it his mother or his father? I want to see his siblings, if he had any. I want the scene he described, of him going to the leaders of his home and presenting his “kill half of the population” idea. I want to see the thought process that led to this madness in action. And most of all, I want scenes of him traveling from world to world with his children, committing mass genocide unchecked. It’ll probably never happen now that he’s no longer in the storyline of the MCU, but I’d still love to see it.

If you had to read only one fanfic trope for the rest of forever, what would it be?

I literally agonized over this question. There are so many tropes that I love, it was almost impossible to settle on one. 

The one I kept coming back to, though, was mutual pining. I love, love, love reading about two nerds who are totally into each other just pining away thinking their feelings are unrequited. It makes for some of the best stories, and it never gets old.

Thanks for the asks! Let’s do it again sometime.

reblog.comment:
These are such good questions - thank you! 

(Buckle up, because this answer is going to be a long one.) 

Thoughts on Thor in Endgame - Spoilers ahead obviously! 

Most of my answer to this question comes from an answer I’d written on Quora, but I’ve added a few things as well. Thor has always been my favorite Avenger, and even before that he was always my favorite Norse god, so I’m really happy to answer this one.

I know people have a lot of feelings about the movie, and I haven’t actually had a chance to write about my own feelings on it much. But one of the things I enjoyed most about Endgame was that everyone got a chance to do something that made their arc complete, for better or worse - i.e

  • Steve’s dance and his happy ending
  • Natasha sacrificing herself and finally wiping the red out of her ledger
  • Clint being willing to sacrifice himself and seeing the error of his ways as Ronin
  • Tony getting to have a few years of domestic bliss and being able to have one last positive conversation with his dad before he selflessly saved the world by giving his own life
  • Bruce and Hulk coming to a peaceful agreement to coexist

But my favorite of those moments was Thor’s visit to 2013 Asgard. 

Up to this point in the movie, Thor has been severely depressed. Though he pretends to be indifferent, it’s painfully obvious that he’s still suffering from all the trauma he’s been through in the last few years (not least of which was losing everyone he loved and failing in his fight with Thanos). His depression shows in his physical appearance and his mental attitude. 

Even when he gets to 2013 Asgard, he doesn’t initially have the motivation to carry out the mission he’s supposed to. It isn’t until Frigga notices him and offers her listening ear that Thor is forced to confront his feelings. His mother, the person who knows him the best, is the one that helps Thor work through those feelings, and I think it’s brilliantly done. Unlike with his friends, Thor is more willing to talk to his mother about how he feels (and for good reason - who wouldn’t feel comfortable confiding in Frigga?). 

He gets a chance to talk about what happened to him without fear of being judged or ridiculed. He knows his mother won’t think less of him because he failed at something - and she doesn’t. In fact, she gives him some really good advice in relation to that: “It’s time for you to stop being who you’re supposed to be, and start being who you are.”

It’s a simple bit of dialogue, but very powerful, and it gives Thor the confidence he needs to get himself together. 

In just that short span of time that he had a chance to talk to his mother, she helps him realize that he is still valuable, and more than that, he’s equal to the task he needs to perform. That confidence boost inspires him to call for his hammer. 

Mjölnir immediately flies into his hand. Softly, with glee, he says, “I’m still worthy!” It was enough to break my heart in the best way possible, and probably my favorite line of dialogue in the whole three hour movie. From that point on, we see Thor get his mojo back, and it’s beautiful. I think it was a great way to round out his arc if that’s what they’re choosing to do. But part of me is hoping that they actually use this as a kickoff point to give us more of his story post-Endgame.

And yeah, I liked chubby Berserker Thor. I also liked that they didn’t waste time showing us some unnecessary montage of him working out and losing weight again. I love that they had him fight as he was, and he was still a badass. Sure, we probably could’ve done without the melted ice cream and salad jokes, but on the whole, I wasn’t unhappy with the way Thor’s arc panned out. 

What MCU character deserves a solo movie? 

I’d actually love to see Thanos get his own movie. Aside from Loki, he’s probably been the most compelling villain for me. The difference between Thanos and Loki is that we got Loki’s “origin story” from the first Thor movie - it helped us understand who he was and where he came from, and it showed us how he ended up on the path that led him to where he was in the first Avengers movie. 

With Thanos, we really get no such backstory. Sure, he talks about it a little bit in Infinity War, but for me it just wasn’t enough. I want to see more than just a passing shot of Titan in all its glory. I want to see young Thanos, find out who Alars is - is it his mother or his father? I want to see his siblings, if he had any. I want the scene he described, of him going to the leaders of his home and presenting his “kill half of the population” idea. I want to see the thought process that led to this madness in action. And most of all, I want scenes of him traveling from world to world with his children, committing mass genocide unchecked. It’ll probably never happen now that he’s no longer in the storyline of the MCU, but I’d still love to see it.

If you had to read only one fanfic trope for the rest of forever, what would it be?

I literally agonized over this question. There are so many tropes that I love, it was almost impossible to settle on one. 

The one I kept coming back to, though, was mutual pining. I love, love, love reading about two nerds who are totally into each other just pining away thinking their feelings are unrequited. It makes for some of the best stories, and it never gets old.

Thanks for the asks! Let’s do it again sometime.

blog.name: cosmicdeity746
blog.title: Anxious, Bi and Ready to Ship
blog.description: She/Her. Bi. Has an annoying habit of obsessing with one fandom, letting it go, then promptly obsessing again at random. Oh, and I also write occasionally.

summary: Tried to explain that the reason I was mad at Avengers: Endgame to my friend due to the sheer lack of female representation....
body:
Tried to explain that the reason I was mad at Avengers: Endgame to my friend due to the sheer lack of female representation. Sure there were scenes that had Nebula and Black Widow in them, but more often than not they were against a male character or weren’t significant enough.

I mentioned how the end fight scene where all the female characters come together to help Captain Marvel (who they preached representation then tables for a good portion of the movie mind you) wasn’t justified or given the weight because none of these women interacted previously through this film or barely even in Infinity War. I said how it was a “oh look how feminist we are, so stop being mad at us”. Also the “first gay Marvel character” made me sick to my stomach because again, not justified and even could be some kind of joke since it was played by a white straight man.

My friend then explained to me that he didn’t feel represented in Black Panther (cis white man that he is) but still enjoyed it all the same, so why can’t I enjoy Endgame. Dismissively as he had preciously done with Captain Marvel. That same movie weeks before he’d complained as being boring since he couldn’t relate to Captain Marvel.

I didn’t have the stomach to argue that he just proved my goddamn point. How many male centric movies has Marvel created. And in them, how often does a female character get time on screen or relevance? The only one is Black Widow. Who they end up giving a regurgitated death to anyway because they had to find a way to explain Black Widow out of the universe anyway so let’s kill her same way we killed Gamora. But let’s change just the sightest bit to give it a “weight” by her “sacrifice”

In conclusion, the white cis male, was exceptionally happy and pleased with the final chapter for “his” movie, since he had been given a lead in the films since day one. While the female bi-sexual is still waiting for a chance to say, “oh that’s relatable” to this day.

PS Black Panther is a superior film.

summary: I'm sorry, I can no longer hold back, these people have the greatest idea ever and I'm so mad we didn't get a scene like that,...
body:
I’m sorry, I can no longer hold back, these people have the greatest idea ever and I’m so mad we didn’t get a scene like that, it would’ve been so POWERFUL, they didn’t need to hurt us to make us feel, I would’ve felt so much, so many things at the same time if this happened, this would’ve been epic! It would’ve been a real “Avengers, assemble!” moment!

All credit to these people: x x (if you are here and posted this here already, I’m sorry, and also know that I love you and your minds)

blog.name: iamdoctorstephenstrange
blog.title: I am Doctor Stephen Strange
blog.description: I am Doctor Stephen Strange, Sorcerer Supreme, guardian of the Eye of Agamotto and your reality, protector of the Sanctum Sanctorum, former neurosurgeon, and now unofficial asset to the Avengers.

summary: Mun: Hey, darlings! Just to be clear, Tony is still alive on this blog! Endgame isn’t entirely canon here, so Tony is still...
body:
Mun: Hey, darlings! Just to be clear, Tony is still alive on this blog! Endgame isn’t entirely canon here, so Tony is still alive, because I’m in denial and the Russos can kiss my arse. Morgan and Pepper still exist, though, and Tony loves them deeply. Still, I’m a slut for IronStrange, so … ;)

Don’t worry, Stephen won’t be a homewrecker. Tony and Pepper parted amicably and Tony still spends a lot of time with them.

Thought I should make this clear. Sorry if there was any confusion!
